Award.AwardTitle: Population and Ordering Dynamics in Bacterial Intestinal Infection
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the PI will study the population and information dynamics that drive the infection of the roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans by the opportunistic bacteria Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The worm offers advantages as a host model: its geometry is simple and it is easy to cultivate and image, while mechanism of infection and innate immune response are evolutionary conserved. The physical locomotion of bacteria within the host, their sensation of the host environment, and their adaptation and collective response will be imaged and quantified. Data will be analyzed and compiled into a theoretical framework, inspired by the physics of population dynamics and the statistical mechanics of ordering phenomena in disordered systems. This project will provide detailed description of within-host bacterial dynamics, believed to be key determinant in evolution of virulence and resistance to infection. While the project will focus on infection of C. elegans, emerging theoretical concepts are expected to be broadly applicable. Novel tools will be developed to permit long-term high-resolution imaging. The true interdisciplinary nature of the project and the general interest in pathogenesis bear the potential to attract a diverse cohort of students. The PI will develop a new course intended for advanced undergraduate and graduate students, which will discuss a spectrum of dynamical biological systems and develop the theoretical and practical aspects of modeling a complex biological system. The PI will establish a discussion group to accompany the project, composed of undergraduate students and public school teachers.

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Physiological and Structural Systems in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interactions between host and pathogen occur over a multitude of time scales and levels of organization. The progression of the infection process, from its inoculation to its final outcome, show large host-to-host variability, and depends on the host life history, its immune response, and its behavioral reactions. In this project the PI and his collaborators used a simple host model, the roundworm C. elegans, to identify characteristics of host response to intestinal infection by the human pathogen P. aeruginosa. Using a simple host allowed the team to address complex questions about the dynamics of infection, the organization of host defense, and the coordination of behavioral response, that are not accessible in more complex organisms.

 

To facilitate the research in this project, the PI and his team developed several technologies. High resolution imaging of the dynamics of the pathogen in the intestine of the host was facilitated by a microfluidic based platform, which confines animals to small chambers and permits imaging of many individual animals over the entire infection process. This platform has many other applications, including investigation of animal response to environmental cues. Another microfluidic-based platform was developed to allow automated imaging of the dynamics of the physiological impacts of infection, including its effect on the animal’s ability to move, on its capacity to sense its environment, on the activation of immune response, and ultimately on its survival. Finally, the team developed an automated imaging workflow for quantification of collective animal response to stress, which has also been used to study the feedback between animals and their environments. Development of all these imaging technologies was accompanied by development of image processing algorithms and tools.

 

An important outcome of this study is a map of the high-level organization of host defense against intestinal pathogens. Combining quantitative imaging with large-scale kinetic study of host gene expression allowed the team to investigate the interactions among different host response pathways, and to identify an important control mechanism in which the nervous systems controls key intestinal immune pathways through a highly conserved energy sensing factors. This study further implicated an important signaling pathway in the coordination of host response, a previously unknown role.

 

Another outcome of this study links early in-host pathogen dynamics with the variable outcome of infection. The team demonstrated that the nucleation of infection is a highly random aggregation process, and that this randomness contributes to the variability of the time and magnitude of proliferation of the pathogen within the host, and eventually to the variability in survival.  

 

While studying the regulation of the uptake of pathogens, the team developed new understandings about the regulation of feeding in response to the presence of food. This is an important question not only for our understanding of pathogen inoculation, but also for questions related with metabolic disorders. The team found that animals control their feeding by modulation the frequency and duration of bursts of feeding, and identified the molecular and neuronal mechanisms behind this mode of regulation. The high-precision observation of feeding dynamics allowed the team to develop a theoretical model that explains the dynamics of feeding as a balance between the need to harness energy and to collect information from the environment.

 

Finally, this study discovered that animals coordinate their behavioral and immune response to pathogens, and identified molecular and neuronal pathways responsible for this collective behavior. These findings suggest that the behavioral response of a host is controlled not only by the presence of the pathogen, but also by the presence of its peers. The potential implications of this outcome call for further investigations.

 

This research project provided training opportunities for several researchers from broad communities. Multidisciplinary research training in physics as well as molecular and organismal biology was provided to both undergraduate and graduate students, including four students from under-represented minorities. In addition, this research project was used to establish a discussion group that introduced inter-disciplinary science to freshmen students whose studies are not focused on the sciences.
